text:
In the last problem, we conducted experiments to find the chances of particular outcomes. We represented the chances as a ratio of two quantities. We can express these ratios in fraction form or as percents. The mathematical word for chance is probability. A probability that we find by conducting an experiment and collecting data is called an experimental probability.

Suppose we toss a paper cup 50 times and it lands on its side 31 times. Favorable outcomes are the outcomes in which a desired result occurs. In this case, a favorable result, landed on its side, occurred 31 times.

To find the experimental probability, we use the part-to-whole ratio.
